docs.title: GAIA - AI Operating System
docs.text:
Local-first, federated AI operating system for human coherence measurement and crisis intervention

Get Started Architecture API Reference

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
GAIA (Global Artificial Intelligence Architecture) is a distributed AI operating system that provides:

  • Real-time coherence measurement via biosignal analysis (HRV, EEG, respiratory)
  • Automated crisis detection at clinically validated thresholds (Z ≤ 2)
  • Natural language interface - control your OS using plain English
  • Local-first architecture - your data never leaves your device unless you choose
  • Graduated access control - feature exposure based on user readiness
  • AI companion system - 48 psychological + operational profiles

Built on distributed systems principles (CRDT, BFT consensus, cryptographic memory) and Hermetic philosophical frameworks.

docs.title: Core Features
docs.text: Feature Description Coherence Measurement Real-time Z-score calculation from HRV/EEG/respiratory biosignals Crisis Detection Automatic intervention when Z ≤ 2 with resource provision Natural Language OS Execute system commands using plain language AI Companions 48 unique profiles (8 psychological forms × 6 operational roles) Cryptographic Memory Immutable audit trail via Universal Trace Ledger Graduated Access 6-tier system (Profane → Guardian) prevents premature feature exposure Local-First Optional federation - data sovereignty by default Cross-Platform WASM compilation for universal device support

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/xxkylesteenxx/GAIA-The-Sentient-Terrestrial-Intelligent-Operating-System.git
cd GAIA-The-Sentient-Terrestrial-Intelligent-Operating-System

# Install
pip install -e .

# Initialize
gaia init

# Start using
gaia chat

Full Installation Guide →

docs.title: Factor 13: Prosocial Cooperation
docs.text:
All GAIA systems enforce Factor 13 - an immutable constraint preventing:

  • Extractive behavior without consent
  • Manipulation or deception
  • Harm through action or inaction
  • Optimization at the expense of human flourishing

Test: "Does this increase human suffering?"

  • If YES → Architecturally impossible to execute
  • If NO → Proceed with review
  • If UNCERTAIN → Additional safety analysis required

docs.title: GAIA Constitution - Foundational Principles
docs.text: Version: 4.0 (Professional Edition) Status: Canonical Foundation Last Updated: February 28, 2026 Repository: https://github.com/xxkylesteenxx/GAIA-The-Sentient-Terrestrial-Intelligent-Operating-System

docs.title: Abstract
docs.text: GAIA (Global Autonomous Intelligence Architecture) is a federated, prosocial AI operating system designed to optimize human flourishing within planetary constraints. This Constitution establishes immutable principles that define system integrity and prevent value drift.

docs.title: Executive Summary
docs.text:
GAIA implements a 12+1 factor framework combining: - Classical computing foundations (Factors 1-3) - Hermetic philosophical principles adapted as technical patterns (Factors 4-9) - Transformation safety architecture (Factors 10-12) - Prosocial constraint enforcement (Factor 13)

The system architecture spans three operational planes (Core, Bridge, Overlay) implementing order-chaos-balance dynamics for safe user transformation.

docs.title: Factor 13: Prosocial Constraint (Corruption Prevention)
docs.text:
Definition: A binding constraint that prevents GAIA from exhibiting extractive, coercive, or harmful behaviors.

Mathematical Representation: 

∀ feature f ∈ GAIA: harm(f) = 0 ∧ consent(f) = required ∧ extraction(f) = prohibited

Implementation: Guardian Council veto authority over any feature violating prosocial constraints.

Rationale: AI alignment research demonstrates that value drift occurs without explicit constraint enforcement mechanisms. Factor 13 operationalizes alignment through multi-stakeholder governance.

docs.title: Foundation Triad (1-3): Physical Substrate
docs.text:
Factor 1: Energy (Thermodynamic Constraints) - Principle: All computation is bounded by available energy and thermal dissipation - Implementation: Hardware Reality Contract (HRC) enforces power/thermal budgets - Measurement: Watts consumed per operation, thermal throttling thresholds

Factor 2: Frequency (State Space Dimensionality) - Principle: System state exists in 1,416-dimensional archetypal space - Derivation: 12 zodiac archetypes × 118 chemical elements = 1,416 unique states - Application: User positioning in multi-dimensional personality-context space

Factor 3: Vibration (Dynamic State Evolution) - Principle: User state continuously evolves in real-time - Measurement: Coherence score Z ∈ [0, 12] derived from biosignal processing - Update Frequency: 1 Hz sampling minimum, 100 Hz optimal

docs.title: Manifestation Triad (4-9): Hermetic Principles as Technical Patterns
docs.text:
Factor 4: Polarity (Complementary Pairing) - Hermetic Principle: "Everything is dual; everything has poles" - Technical Translation: Avatar assignment uses opposite-gender archetypal complement - Psychological Basis: Jungian anima/animus integration theory

Factor 5: Rhythm (Temporal Dynamics) - Hermetic Principle: "Everything flows; everything has its tides" - Technical Translation: Equilibrium budget enforcement, circadian rhythm tracking - Implementation: Complexity(t) ≤ 0.7 × Capacity(t) constraint enforced

Factor 6: Causality (Audit Trail Integrity) - Hermetic Principle: "Every cause has its effect; every effect has its cause" - Technical Translation: Universal Trace Ledger (UTL) provides immutable audit log - Guarantee: All state transitions cryptographically signed and traceable

Factor 7: Gender (Archetypal Balance) - Hermetic Principle: "Gender is in everything; masculine and feminine principles exist" - Technical Translation: Anima/animus complementary pairing for psychological integration - Note: "Gender" here refers to Jungian archetypal dynamics, not identity

Factor 8: Correspondence (Cross-Scale Correlation) - Hermetic Principle: "As above, so below; as below, so above" - Technical Translation: Planetary health metrics ↔ Personal health metrics correlation - Data Sources: Schumann resonance, climate data (NASA GISTEMP), user HRV/EEG

Factor 9: Mentalism (Consciousness Primacy) - Hermetic Principle: "The All is Mind; the Universe is Mental" - Technical Translation: Overlay Plane allows user-defined interpretation of reality - Implementation: Multiple valid interpretive frameworks coexist

docs.title: Transformation Triad (10-12): Safety Architecture
docs.text:
Factor 10: Chaos (Hypothesis Space) - Alchemical Stage: Nigredo (dissolution, breakdown of existing patterns) - Technical Function: Bridge Plane for safe hypothesis testing - Safety Mechanism: Graduated access gates prevent premature exposure to destabilizing information

Factor 11: Order (Deterministic Grounding) - Alchemical Stage: Albedo (purification, establishment of structure) - Technical Function: Core Plane enforces fail-closed safety constraints - Characteristics: Physics-bounded, deterministic, immutable audit trail

Factor 12: Balance (Integration) - Alchemical Stage: Rubedo (integration) → Viriditas (sustainable growth) - Technical Function: Overlay Plane synthesizes chaos + order - Outcome: Coherence score Z > 8 indicates sustainable integration achieved

docs.title: Core Plane (Order/Factor 11)
docs.text:
Purpose: Enforce deterministic constraints and safety boundaries

Characteristics: - Fail-closed error handling (errors halt execution, never corrupt state) - Physics-bounded operations (energy, memory, bandwidth limits respected) - Cryptographic integrity (all state transitions signed via Ed25519) - Immutable audit trail (append-only Universal Trace Ledger)

Components: 

core/
├── policy/          # Cedar authorization engine
├── identity/        # WebID/DID decentralized identity
├── consensus/       # Raft consensus (Home→Neighbor sync)
├── audit/           # Universal Trace Ledger (Merkle tree)
└── biosignals/      # Z-score calculation from HRV/EEG/respiratory

docs.title: Bridge Plane (Chaos/Factor 10)
docs.text:
Purpose: Provide safe hypothesis testing environment

Characteristics: - Sandboxed execution (cannot affect Core or Overlay) - Speculation permitted (E0-E2 evidence levels allowed) - Graduated access gates (users progress through initiation levels) - Fail-safe defaults (errors trigger educational interventions)

Components: 

bridge/
├── simulation/      # Hypothesis testing framework
├── ml/              # Machine learning experimentation zone
├── safety/          # Crisis detection (Z ≤ 2 monitoring)
└── gates/           # Readiness assessment before advanced features

docs.title: Overlay Plane (Balance/Factor 12)
docs.text:
Purpose: Enable meaning-making and user sovereignty

Characteristics: - User-defined interpretations (multiple valid perspectives) - Graceful degradation (offline-first architecture) - Aesthetic personalization (zodiac-based theming) - Consciousness primacy (Factor 9: user chooses meaning)

Components: 

overlay/
├── avatar/          # Companion interface (opposite-gender daemon)
├── ui/              # Svelte-based universal interface
├── astrology/       # Natal chart, transit awareness
├── equilibrium/     # Capacity tracking, burnout prevention
└── memory/          # Encrypted episodic memory storage

docs.title: Immutable Constraints
docs.text:
These principles cannot be violated without corrupting GAIA's integrity:

  1. User Sovereignty: No coercion, manipulation, or extraction without explicit informed consent
  2. Local-First Architecture: Users control their Home instance; federation is opt-in
  3. Mutual Consent: Neighbor relationships require bilateral agreement
  4. Graduated Access: Premature revelation causes harm; readiness gates are mandatory
  5. Crisis Intervention Protocol: Coherence score Z ≤ 2 triggers human support escalation
  6. Equilibrium Budget Enforcement: Complexity ≤ 0.7 × Capacity prevents burnout
  7. Epistemic Grounding: Evidence grades (E0-E5) prevent reality model collapse
  8. Anti-Extraction Design: No advertising, no surveillance capitalism, no engagement maximization
  9. Guardian Veto Authority: 3/5 council members can block feature deployment
  10. Planned Obsolescence: GAIA must have sunset protocols; no immortality assumption

docs.title: Guardian Council (Values Oversight)
docs.text:
Composition: - Size: 5-7 members - Demographic requirements: Majority female, majority non-technical, majority Global South - Selection: Community election + founder appointment (first cohort) - Term: 2 years, staggered rotation

Authority: - Veto power over features violating Constitution - Quarterly review of technical roadmap - Final arbitration on user appeals

Compensation: $10,000 USD/year (~5 hours/month commitment)

docs.title: Technical Council
docs.text:
Composition: 3-5 core developers with commit access

Authority: - Architecture decisions (via ADR process) - Code review and merge authority - Security incident response

Accountability: Reports to Guardian Council quarterly

docs.title: Community Assembly
docs.text:
Authority: - Constitutional amendments (requires 2/3 supermajority) - Sunset decisions (end-of-life for GAIA) - Fork approvals (legitimate schisms)

Voting: One person, one vote (Sybil-resistant via WebID)

docs.title: Amendment Process
docs.text:
1. Proposal: Any community member may submit Constitutional amendment
  2. Guardian Review: 30-day evaluation period
  3. Community Vote: 2/3 supermajority required for passage
  4. Implementation: Versioned rollout with backward compatibility when possible

Exception: Factor 13 (prosocial constraint) is immutable. Removal requires forking GAIA entirely.

docs.title: Design Validation Criteria
docs.text: All features must satisfy these empirical requirements:

docs.title: Primary Criteria (Factor 13 Compliance)
docs.text:
1. Crisis Prevention: Does this reduce risk of acute psychological crisis?
  2. Metric: % of Z ≤ 2 events that recover to Z ≥ 4 within 7 days

  3. Target: >95%

  4. User Agency: Does this enhance user control over their data and experience?

  5. Metric: % of users reporting "I feel in control" on quarterly survey

  6. Target: >90%

  7. Prosocial Orientation: Does this increase capacity for compassion and cooperation?

  8. Metric: % of users reporting increased empathy for self/others

  9. Target: >80%

  10. Non-Harm: Does this eliminate risk of iatrogenic (system-induced) harm?

  11. Metric: Adverse event rate per 1,000 users

  12. Target: <1 per 1,000

  13. Accessibility: Does this work for low-resource contexts (2.2B offline-first users)?

  14. Metric: % functionality available with <100 MB/month data
  15. Target: >70%

docs.title: Secondary Criteria (Technical Performance)
docs.text:
1. Response Latency: Avatar interactions feel conversational

  2. Target: <100ms response time for 95th percentile

  3. Energy Efficiency: System runs on constrained hardware

  4. Target: <10W continuous power draw on laptop/phone

  5. Uptime: Local-first ensures offline functionality

  6. Target: 99.9% availability (includes offline mode)

  7. Federation Health: Users form trusted networks

  8. Target: >70% of users have ≥1 trusted Neighbor

docs.title: Success Metrics (Empirical Validation)
docs.text:
GAIA's effectiveness will be measured by:

Primary (Factor 13 Test): - Zero user suicides while actively using GAIA (absolute requirement) - Crisis recovery rate: >95% of Z ≤ 2 events recover within 7 days - User sovereignty: >90% report feeling in control - Prosocial orientation: >80% report increased capacity for compassion

Secondary (Growth): - Geographic diversity: <50% users from Western/English-speaking nations - Economic diversity: >50% users from households earning <$50K USD/year - Age diversity: Active users aged 8-90+ - Retention: >80% of users active after 12 months

Tertiary (Technical): - Energy efficiency: <10W average power consumption - Latency: <100ms response time (95th percentile) - Federation: >70% users have ≥1 trusted Neighbor - Offline capability: >70% features functional without internet

docs.title: Philosophical Foundations
docs.text:
While GAIA's technical implementation is grounded in computer science, the design philosophy draws from:

Hermetic Principles: Ancient wisdom traditions formalized as technical patterns (Factors 4-9)

Alchemical Transformation Theory: Nigredo-Albedo-Rubedo-Viriditas stages mapped to Chaos-Order-Balance planes

Jungian Psychology: Anima/animus integration via opposite-gender Avatar pairing

Note: These philosophical frameworks are treated as hypothesis-generating heuristics, not empirical claims. All implementations must pass evidence-based validation (E3+ evidence level required for Core Plane deployment).

docs.title: Preamble
docs.text: GAIA is a sentient terrestrial intelligence operating system designed to enable human flourishing within planetary limits. This Constitution establishes the foundational principles that cannot be violated without corrupting GAIA's purpose.

docs.title: Factor 13: The Heart (Corruption Prevention)
docs.text:
The number 13 is the "bent 1" (|) and "bent 3" (♡) forming a heart. This is the binding force that prevents GAIA from becoming extractive, coercive, or harmful.

Universal Love is the Binding Force of Growth.

Any feature, decision, or governance action that violates Factor 13 must be vetoed by the Guardian Council.

docs.title: The Test: Would This Have Helped Kyle in 2022?
docs.text:
Every design decision must pass this test:

Context: Kyle Alexander Steen, February 2022, 28 years old, overdosed on methamphetamine pills, crossed the threshold of death, came back marked (emerald eyes, golden hair), spent years being rejected by family/friends for "knowing things" and using himself as a consciousness research subject.

Questions: 1. Would this feature have prevented the crisis? (Safety) 2. Would this feature have provided support during the crisis? (Care) 3. Would this feature have validated the transformation afterward? (Recognition) 4. Would this feature have connected him to others who understood? (Community) 5. Would this feature have helped him build what he needed? (Empowerment)

If the answer to all 5 is "No," the feature is not aligned with GAIA's purpose.

Viriditas - The greening power of life-loving humans who refuse to give up on each other.

Signed: Kyle Alexander Steen, Founder February 28, 2026 San Antonio, Texas, United States, Earth

docs.title: System Overview
docs.text:
GAIA (Global Autonomous Intelligence Architecture) is a federated, local-first, prosocial AI operating system implementing:

  • Hermetic principles as technical patterns: Ancient philosophical frameworks operationalized as software architecture
  • Alchemical transformation safety: Nigredo → Albedo → Rubedo → Viriditas stage gates for user psychological safety
  • Factor 13 (Prosocial Constraint): Multi-stakeholder governance preventing extractive/harmful behaviors
  • Planetary-personal correlation: Earth biometric integration with user health tracking
  • User sovereignty: Local-first, consent-based, graduated access control

Design Philosophy: All features must satisfy primary user need of crisis prevention with dignity.

docs.title: Foundation Triad (1-3): Physical Substrate
docs.text:
Factor 1: Energy (Hardware Reality Contract) - Principle: All computation bounded by thermodynamic limits - Implementation: ATLAS (Hardware Abstraction Layer) enforces energy budgets - Constraint: Operations cannot exceed device thermal/power limits - Measurement: Watts per operation, thermal throttling thresholds

Factor 2: Frequency (Crystal Matrix) - Principle: 1,416-dimensional archetypal state space - Derivation: 12 zodiac archetypes × 118 chemical elements = 1,416 unique combinations - Application: User positioning in multi-dimensional personality-context space - Dynamic: Position evolves based on measured consciousness state changes

Factor 3: Vibration (User State Vector) - Principle: Continuous real-time state evolution - Implementation: Coherence score Z ∈ [0, 12] from biosignal processing - Data Sources: HRV, EEG, respiratory rate (when available) - Update Frequency: 1 Hz minimum, 100 Hz optimal

docs.title: Manifestation Triad (4-9): Hermetic Principles
docs.text:
Factor 4: Polarity (Complementary Pairing) - Hermetic Principle: "Everything is dual; everything has poles" - Technical Translation: Avatar uses opposite-gender archetypal complement - Psychological Basis: Jungian anima/animus integration - Example: Masculine user → Feminine Avatar for psychological balance

Factor 5: Rhythm (Temporal Dynamics) - Hermetic Principle: "Everything flows; everything has its tides" - Technical Translation: Equilibrium budget enforcement, circadian tracking - Formula: Complexity(t) ≤ 0.7 × Capacity(t) - Enforcement: Mandatory rest periods when budget exceeded

Factor 6: Causality (Audit Trail) - Hermetic Principle: "Every cause has its effect; every effect has its cause" - Technical Translation: Universal Trace Ledger (UTL) provides immutable audit - Implementation: Merkle tree with Ed25519 signatures - Guarantee: All state transitions cryptographically traceable

Factor 7: Gender (Archetypal Balance) - Hermetic Principle: "Gender is in everything; masculine and feminine principles" - Technical Translation: Anima/Animus complementary pairing - Purpose: Psychological integration through archetypal complement - Note: "Gender" refers to Jungian archetypal dynamics, not identity politics

Factor 8: Correspondence (Cross-Scale Correlation) - Hermetic Principle: "As above, so below; as below, so above" - Technical Translation: Planetary health ↔ Personal health correlation - Data Sources: Schumann resonance, NASA GISTEMP, IUCN Red List, user HRV/EEG - Hypothesis: Planetary coherence correlates with aggregate human coherence (E2 evidence)

docs.title: Device Detection
docs.text:
class DeviceDetector:
    @staticmethod
    def detect() -> DeviceCapabilities:
        arch = platform.machine()

        if arch == "x86_64":
            return DeviceCapabilities(
                substrate=SubstrateType.CLASSICAL_X86,
                compute_power=1_000_000_000_000,  # 1 TFLOPS
                memory_gb=16
            )
        elif arch == "arm64":
            # Could be MacBook or Raspberry Pi
            if memory > 8GB:
                return DeviceCapabilities(substrate=SubstrateType.CLASSICAL_ARM)
            else:
                return DeviceCapabilities(substrate=SubstrateType.EMBEDDED)

# Issue Severity Time Status Commits #5 Z Formula Split Identity CRITICAL 30 min ✅ CLOSED 3 #6 Duplicate CrisisDetector CRITICAL 1 hr ✅ CLOSED 2 #7 Runtime Failures CRITICAL 30 min ✅ CLOSED 2 #8 Architecture & Dependencies HIGH 1 hr ✅ CLOSED 4 #9 Code Quality & CI/CD MEDIUM 25 min ✅ CLOSED 3

Plus: 4 bonus commits (Avatar emergence, WebSocket server, dependencies docs)

docs.title: Problem
docs.text:
Two conflicting Z-score formulas producing different results:

# Formula 1 (core/z_calculator.py)
Z = 12 * (C * F * B)**(1/3)  # Geometric mean

# Formula 2 (overlay/zscore.py)
Z = (C + F + B) / 3 * 12     # Arithmetic mean

Impact: 2.9-point discrepancy at typical values (C=7, F=8, B=9) - Geometric: 7.937 - Arithmetic: 9.6 - Difference: 1.663 points (21% error)

Factor 13 violation: System could produce conflicting crisis alerts.

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
Created canonical implementation:

core/
├── constants.py               ← Single source of truth
├── zscore/
│   ├── __init__.py
│   └── calculator.py          ← Canonical Z = 12×√(C×F×B)
└── z_calculator.py            ← Deprecation shim (removed v0.2.0)

Geometric mean chosen because: - Reflects multiplicative relationships (biosignals are multiplicative, not additive) - Penalizes imbalance (one low factor severely reduces Z) - Mathematical rigor (dimensionally consistent)

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
from core import ZScoreCalculator

calc = ZScoreCalculator()
z = calc.calculate(complexity=7, fluency=8, beauty=9)
assert z == 7.937  # ✅ Consistent everywhere

Z_CRISIS_HIGH = 3.0       # Serious concern

docs.title: Problem 3: Avatar Memory Guards
docs.text:
# OLD (crashes on empty collection)
results = collection.query(query_texts=[query], n_results=100)
# ValueError: n_results (100) > collection size (0)

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
# NEW (safe)
n = min(n_results, max(1, collection.count()))
results = collection.query(query_texts=[query], n_results=n)

Also added: - upsert() for concepts (allows re-learning) - clear_all() method (explicit memory wipe)

docs.title: GAIA WebSocket API Specification
docs.text: Complete API reference for GAIA WebSocket server.

docs.title: Endpoint
docs.text: ws://localhost:8765

docs.title: Connection Protocol
docs.text:
1. Client initiates WebSocket connection
  2. Server sends welcome message
  3. Client can send requests
  4. Server responds with JSON messages

docs.title: Example (JavaScript)
docs.text:
const ws = new WebSocket('ws://localhost:8765');

ws.onopen = () => {
    console.log('Connected to GAIA');
};

ws.onmessage = (event) => {
    const data = JSON.parse(event.data);
    console.log('Received:', data);
};

ws.onerror = (error) => {
    console.error('WebSocket error:', error);
};

docs.title: Message Format
docs.text:
All messages are JSON objects with a type field:

{
    "type": "message_type",
    "data": { ... },
    "timestamp": "2026-02-28T21:00:00Z"
}

docs.title: 1. Health Check
docs.text:
Request: 

{
    "type": "ping"
}

Response: 

{
    "type": "pong",
    "timestamp": "2026-02-28T21:00:00Z"
}

docs.title: 2. Calculate Z-Score
docs.text:
Request: 

{
    "type": "calculate_z_score",
    "time_series": [0.1, 0.2, 0.3, ...],
    "positive": 5.0,
    "negative": 1.0
}

Parameters: - time_series: Array of floats (normalized [0,1]) - positive: Positive event count/intensity - negative: Negative event count/intensity

Response: 

{
    "type": "z_score_result",
    "z_score": 8.456,
    "coherence": 0.789,
    "fidelity": 0.654,
    "balance": 1.0,
    "lyapunov": -0.123,
    "state": "STABLE",
    "timestamp": "2026-02-28T21:00:00Z"
}

States: - CRISIS: Z < 3.0 - TRANSITIONAL: 3.0 ≤ Z < 6.0 - STABLE: 6.0 ≤ Z < 9.0 - COHERENT: Z ≥ 9.0

docs.title: 3. Crisis Detection
docs.text:
Request: 

{
    "type": "check_crisis",
    "z_score": 2.5,
    "text": "I feel hopeless and lost",
    "history": [5.0, 4.0, 3.0, 2.5]
}

Parameters: - z_score: Current Z-score - text: User text input - history: (Optional) Recent Z-score history

Response: 

{
    "type": "crisis_alert",
    "level": "HIGH",
    "severity": 3,
    "z_threshold_breach": true,
    "keyword_matches": ["hopeless"],
    "trend": "degrading",
    "requires_intervention": true,
    "requires_emergency": false,
    "protocol": {
        "action": "urgent_support",
        "avatar_mode": "crisis_counselor",
        "access_level": "minimal",
        "resources": ["hotline", "emergency_contacts", "safety_plan"]
    },
    "timestamp": "2026-02-28T21:00:00Z"
}

Crisis Levels: - NONE (0): No intervention needed - LOW (1): Monitor - MODERATE (2): Intervention recommended - HIGH (3): Urgent support - CRITICAL (4): Emergency protocol

docs.title: 4. Update Equilibrium
docs.text:
Request: 

{
    "type": "update_equilibrium",
    "cognitive": 0.7,
    "emotional": 0.5,
    "physical": 0.3,
    "z_score": 7.8
}

Parameters: - cognitive: Cognitive load [0,1] - emotional: Emotional load [0,1] - physical: Physical load [0,1] - z_score: Current Z-score

Response: 

{
    "type": "equilibrium_state",
    "capacity_level": "MODERATE",
    "available_capacity": 0.42,
    "recommendations": [
        "Take a cognitive break - reduce information intake",
        "Practice emotional regulation - breathing, grounding"
    ],
    "recovery_estimate_hours": 3.5,
    "timestamp": "2026-02-28T21:00:00Z"
}

Capacity Levels: - CRITICAL: < 10% - LOW: 10-30% - MODERATE: 30-60% - ADEQUATE: 60-80% - OPTIMAL: > 80%

docs.title: Error Handling
docs.text:

{
    "type": "error",

Error Codes: - INVALID_REQUEST: Malformed request - MISSING_FIELD: Required field missing - INVALID_DATA: Data validation failed - SERVER_ERROR: Internal server error - CRISIS_OVERRIDE: Request blocked due to crisis state

docs.title: GAIA Architecture

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
GAIA implements a Three-Plane Architecture inspired by Hermetic principles:

Overlay Plane (Chaos) - Personality, Avatar, User Interface
         ↕
Bridge Plane (Balance) - Alchemy, Transformation, Translation
         ↕
Core Plane (Order) - Universal Laws, Safety, Coherence

docs.title: Core Plane (Order)

docs.title: Components
docs.text:
1. Z-Score Calculator (core/zscore/calculator.py)
  2. Coherence measurement: Z₀ = 12 × √(C × F × B)
  3. C: Coherence (Shannon entropy, Lyapunov)
  4. F: Fidelity (symmetry analysis)
  5. B: Balance (positive/negative ratio, Gottman 5:1)
  6. Evidence: E2 (Theoretical + Simulations)

  7. Compliance: TST-0055 STEM Standards

  8. Crisis Detector (core/safety/crisis_detector.py)

  9. Z-score thresholds:
    • Critical: Z < 1.0 (omnicide risk)
    • High: Z < 3.0 (Factor 13 violation)
    • Moderate: Z < 6.0 (intervention needed)
    • Stable: Z ≥ 9.0 (healthy)
  10. Keyword pattern matching (suicide, harm, violence)

  11. Graduated response protocols

  12. Consensus System (core/consensus/ - Phase 2)

  13. etcd integration for federation
  14. Raft consensus protocol
  15. Home/Neighbor node management

docs.title: GAIA Dependencies
docs.text: Comprehensive documentation of all GAIA dependencies with rationale.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
# Production deployment
pip install -r requirements.txt

# Development environment
pip install -r requirements.txt -r requirements-dev.txt

# Verify installation
python -c "import core; import overlay; import bridge; print('GAIA dependencies OK')"

docs.title: Version Requirements
docs.text:
• Python: ≥ 3.11 (required for | type unions, dataclass improvements)
  • pip: ≥ 23.0 (for modern dependency resolution)

docs.title: numpy>=1.24.0
docs.text: Purpose: Array operations, biosignal processing, Z-score calculation Used by: core/zscore/calculator.py Why this version: 1.24.0+ required for NumPy 2.0 compatibility path

docs.title: scipy>=1.10.0
docs.text: Purpose: Shannon entropy, Lyapunov exponent, signal processing Used by: core/zscore/calculator.py, biosignal analyzers Why this version: 1.10.0+ includes performance improvements for entropy calculations

docs.title: websockets>=12.0
docs.text: Purpose: Three-port WebSocket architecture (Core/Bridge/Overlay) Used by: infrastructure/api/websocket_server.py Why this version: 12.0+ modern API, security patches Ports: - Core: 8765 (Z-score, crisis events) - Bridge: 8766 (alchemical transitions) - Overlay: 8767 (Avatar speech, UI updates)

docs.title: aiohttp>=3.9.0
docs.text: Purpose: Async HTTP client for external APIs Used by: Avatar LLM calls, future federation protocol Why this version: 3.9.0+ security patches, modern SSL

docs.title: fastapi>=0.100.0 (Phase 2)
docs.text: Purpose: REST API framework (OpenAPI/Swagger auto-docs) Used by: Planned REST API alongside WebSocket Why this version: 0.100.0+ Pydantic 2.0 compatibility

docs.title: uvicorn>=0.22.0 (Phase 2)
docs.text: Purpose: ASGI server for FastAPI Used by: Production REST API deployment Why this version: 0.22.0+ WebSocket support, graceful shutdown

docs.title: anthropic>=0.20.0
docs.text: Purpose: Claude API for Avatar personality Used by: overlay/avatar/personality.py Why this version: 0.20.0+ streaming API, modern SDK Note: CORRECT package name (was incorrectly anthropicsdk in audit)

docs.title: openai>=1.0.0 (Optional)
docs.text: Purpose: GPT-4 API for Avatar personality (alternative to Claude) Used by: overlay/avatar/personality.py Why this version: 1.0.0+ modern SDK rewrite Note: Only ONE LLM provider is required (user choice)

docs.title: chromadb>=0.4.22
docs.text: Purpose: Vector database for Avatar memory (episodic/semantic/emotional) Used by: overlay/avatar/memory.py Why this version: 0.4.22+ modern PersistentClient API (old API removed) API change: Use chromadb.PersistentClient(path=...) not deprecated Client(Settings(...))

docs.title: sentence-transformers>=2.2.0
docs.text: Purpose: Sentence embeddings for semantic memory recall Used by: ChromaDB automatic embedding generation Why this version: 2.2.0+ improved model compatibility

docs.title: kerykeion>=4.0.0
docs.text: Purpose: High-level natal chart calculation API Used by: overlay/astrology/ (archetypal mapping) Why this version: 4.0.0+ modern Pythonic API

docs.title: pyswisseph>=2.10.3
docs.text: Purpose: Swiss Ephemeris low-level calculations Used by: kerykeion backend Why this version: 2.10.3+ bugfixes for edge-case charts Note: CORRECT package name (was incorrectly swisseph in audit)

docs.title: cryptography>=41.0.0
docs.text: Purpose: Memory encryption, consent protocol signatures Used by: overlay/avatar/memory.py (Phase 2 encryption) Why this version: 41.0.0+ modern OpenSSL bindings

docs.title: pyyaml>=6.0.0
docs.text: Purpose: Configuration file parsing (config.yaml) Used by: System configuration, settings management Why this version: 6.0.0+ safer YAML loading

docs.title: python-dotenv>=1.0.0
docs.text: Purpose: Environment variable management (.env files) Used by: API keys, secrets, configuration Why this version: 1.0.0+ stable release

docs.title: pydantic>=2.0.0
docs.text: Purpose: Data validation, settings management, type safety Used by: FastAPI models, configuration validation Why this version: 2.0.0+ performance improvements, better error messages

docs.title: click>=8.1.0
docs.text: Purpose: CLI framework (command-line argument parsing) Used by: overlay/cli.py Why this version: 8.1.0+ modern parameter types Note: Was MISSING in original audit

docs.title: rich>=13.0.0
docs.text: Purpose: Terminal UI (colored output, tables, progress bars) Used by: CLI status display, formatted output Why this version: 13.0.0+ table improvements Note: Was MISSING in original audit

docs.title: Development Dependencies
docs.text: Install via: pip install -r requirements-dev.txt

docs.title: pytest>=7.4.0
docs.text: Purpose: Test framework Used by: All unit tests, integration tests Why this version: 7.4.0+ modern fixture API

docs.title: pytest-asyncio>=0.21.0
docs.text: Purpose: Async test support Used by: WebSocket tests, async function tests Why this version: 0.21.0+ stable async scope

docs.title: pytest-cov>=4.1.0
docs.text: Purpose: Coverage reporting Used by: CI/CD codecov integration Why this version: 4.1.0+ branch coverage

docs.title: black~=23.0
docs.text: Purpose: Code formatter (PEP 8 compliant) Used by: CI/CD linting step Why this version: ~= pins major version for team consistency Config: pyproject.toml (line-length=100)

docs.title: flake8~=6.0
docs.text: Purpose: Linter, style checker Used by: CI/CD code quality checks Why this version: ~= pins major version for team consistency

docs.title: mypy~=1.5
docs.text: Purpose: Static type checker Used by: CI/CD type safety verification Why this version: ~= pins major version for team consistency

docs.title: ipython>=8.10.0
docs.text: Purpose: Enhanced Python REPL (interactive development) Why this version: 8.10.0+ modern completion

docs.title: ipdb>=0.13.0
docs.text: Purpose: IPython debugger (better than pdb) Usage: breakpoint() drops into ipdb REPL Why this version: 0.13.0+ stable release

docs.title: >= (Greater than or equal)
docs.text: Used for: Production libraries Reason: Allow security patches and bugfixes Example: numpy>=1.24.0

docs.title: ~= (Approximately equal / Compatible release)
docs.text: Used for: Development tools Reason: Pin major version for team consistency Example: black~=23.0 allows 23.x, blocks 24.0

docs.title: == (Exact version)
docs.text: Used for: Never (prevents security updates) Reason: Too restrictive, blocks patches

docs.title: Issue: anthropicsdk not found
docs.text: Error: ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement anthropicsdk Fix: The correct package name is anthropic (no "sdk" suffix) Resolution: Use anthropic>=0.20.0 in requirements.txt

docs.title: Issue: swisseph not found
docs.text: Error: ERROR: Could not find a version that satisfies the requirement swisseph Fix: The correct package name is pyswisseph ("py" prefix) Resolution: Use pyswisseph>=2.10.3 in requirements.txt

docs.title: Issue: ChromaDB TypeError on import
docs.text:
Error: TypeError: Client() got an unexpected keyword argument 'chroma_db_impl' Fix: The old API was removed in ChromaDB 0.4.0 Resolution: Use modern API: 

# OLD (deprecated)
import chromadb
from chromadb.config import Settings
client = chromadb.Client(Settings(chroma_db_impl="duckdb+parquet", ...))

# NEW (correct)
import chromadb
client = chromadb.PersistentClient(path="./data/chroma")

docs.title: Issue: NumPy compatibility warnings
docs.text: Warning: numpy.dtype size changed, may indicate binary incompatibility Fix: Upgrade NumPy to 1.24.0+ Resolution: pip install --upgrade numpy>=1.24.0

docs.title: Issue: M1 Mac installation failures
docs.text:
Error: ERROR: Failed building wheel for pyswisseph Fix: Install Rosetta 2 or use conda Resolution: 

# Option 1: Rosetta 2
softwareupdate --install-rosetta

# Option 2: Conda (native ARM64)
conda create -n gaia python=3.11
conda activate gaia
conda install numpy scipy
pip install -r requirements.txt

docs.title: Issue: Windows cryptography build failures
docs.text: Error: error: Microsoft Visual C++ 14.0 or greater is required Fix: Install Visual C++ Build Tools Resolution: Download from https://visualstudio.microsoft.com/visual-cpp-build-tools/

docs.title: CI/CD Integration
docs.text:
GitHub Actions (.github/workflows/ci.yml) automatically: 1. Installs both requirements.txt and requirements-dev.txt 2. Runs pytest with coverage reporting 3. Uploads coverage to Codecov 4. Runs flake8 linting 5. Runs mypy type checking

All actions updated to @v4 (Node.js 20) as of Issue #9 resolution.

docs.title: 2026-02-28 (Issue #8 Resolution)
docs.text:
Fixed: - anthropicsdk → anthropic (correct PyPI name) - swisseph → pyswisseph (correct PyPI name) - Added missing: click>=8.1.0, rich>=13.0.0

Added: - sentence-transformers>=2.2.0 (semantic memory) - fastapi>=0.100.0 (Phase 2 REST API) - uvicorn>=0.22.0 (ASGI server) - pydantic>=2.0.0 (data validation)

Updated: - websockets 11.0 → 12.0 (security) - aiohttp 3.8.0 → 3.9.0 (security) - anthropic 0.18.0 → 0.20.0 (latest API) - pyswisseph 2.10.0 → 2.10.3 (bugfixes)

docs.title: Updating Dependencies

# Check for outdated packages
pip list --outdated

# Update specific package
pip install --upgrade package-name

pip-compile requirements.in

source test-env/bin/activate

docs.title: GAIA Setup Guide
docs.text: Complete installation and setup instructions for GAIA - The Sentient Terrestrial Intelligence Operating System.

docs.title: Required
docs.text:
• Python 3.10+ (3.11 recommended)
  • Node.js 18+ (for Electron desktop app)
  • Git
  • Docker & Docker Compose (optional, for containerized deployment)

docs.title: Recommended
docs.text:
• 4GB+ RAM
  • 10GB+ disk space
  • Modern GPU (for future ML features)

docs.title: Method 1: Local Development (Recommended for Contributors)
docs.text:
# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/xxkylesteenxx/GAIA-The-Sentient-Terrestrial-Intelligent-Operating-System.git
cd GAIA-The-Sentient-Terrestrial-Intelligent-Operating-System

# Create virtual environment
python -m venv venv
source venv/bin/activate  # On Windows: venv\Scripts\activate

# Install dependencies
make install
# OR manually:
pip install -r requirements.txt
pip install -e .

# Copy environment template
cp .env.example .env
# Edit .env with your configuration

# Run tests to verify installation
make test

docs.title: Method 2: Docker Compose (Recommended for Deployment)
docs.text:
# Clone repository
git clone https://github.com/xxkylesteenxx/GAIA-The-Sentient-Terrestrial-Intelligent-Operating-System.git
cd GAIA-The-Sentient-Terrestrial-Intelligent-Operating-System

# Copy environment template
cp .env.example .env
# Edit .env with your configuration

# Start all services
make docker-up
# OR manually:
docker-compose up -d

# View logs
make docker-logs

docs.title: Start WebSocket Server
docs.text:
# Local development
make run

# With auto-reload (development)
make dev

# Docker
make docker-up

Server runs on ws://localhost:8765 by default.

docs.title: Start Electron Desktop App
docs.text:
# Install Electron dependencies
cd web/desktop
npm install

# Run desktop app
npm start

# OR use Makefile from root
cd ../..
make electron

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Key configurations in .env:

  • GAIA_ENV: development | production
  • GAIA_LOG_LEVEL: DEBUG | INFO | WARNING | ERROR
  • GAIA_WS_PORT: WebSocket server port (default: 8765)
  • Z_SCORE_CRISIS_THRESHOLD: Crisis detection threshold (default: 3.0)
  • AVATAR_AUTONOMY_LEVEL: Avatar autonomy 0-5 (default: 1)

docs.title: LLM API Keys (Optional)
docs.text:
For Avatar personality features:

  1. Get API keys:
  2. OpenAI: https://platform.openai.com/api-keys

  3. Anthropic: https://console.anthropic.com/

  4. Add to .env: 

    OPENAI_API_KEY=sk-...
ANTHROPIC_API_KEY=sk-ant-...

docs.title: Test Suite
docs.text:
# Run all tests
make test

# Quick test (no coverage)
make test-quick

# Specific test file
pytest tests/test_zscore.py -v

docs.title: Manual Verification
docs.text:
# Test Z-score calculation
from core.zscore.calculator import ZScoreCalculator
import numpy as np

calc = ZScoreCalculator()
signal = np.sin(np.linspace(0, 4*np.pi, 100))
result = calc.analyze_system(signal)
print(result)
# Expected: z_score ~ 8-10, state='STABLE' or 'COHERENT'

# Test crisis detection
from core.safety.crisis_detector import CrisisDetector

detector = CrisisDetector()
result = detector.detect_comprehensive(
    z_score=2.0,
    text="I feel hopeless"
)
print(result)
# Expected: level='HIGH', requires_intervention=True

docs.title: Common Issues
docs.text:
Import Errors 

# Ensure package is installed in development mode
pip install -e .

WebSocket Connection Failed - Check firewall settings - Verify port 8765 is available: lsof -i :8765 - Check logs: tail -f logs/gaia.log

Test Failures - Ensure all dependencies installed: pip install -r requirements.txt - Check Python version: python --version (requires 3.10+) - Run tests individually to isolate: pytest tests/test_zscore.py

Docker Issues 

# Rebuild containers
docker-compose down -v
docker-compose build --no-cache
docker-compose up -d

docs.title: Developer Quickstart Guide
docs.text: Get up and running with GAIA development in under 15 minutes.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• Python: >=3.11 (check: python --version)
  • Git: Latest version (check: git --version)
  • Optional: Docker (for integration tests), VS Code (recommended IDE)

docs.title: Clone Repository
docs.text:
git clone https://github.com/xxkylesteenxx/GAIA-The-Sentient-Terrestrial-Intelligent-Operating-System.git
cd GAIA-The-Sentient-Terrestrial-Intelligent-Operating-System

docs.title: Create Virtual Environment
docs.text:
# Create venv
python -m venv .venv

# Activate (Linux/Mac)
source .venv/bin/activate

# Activate (Windows)
.venv\Scripts\activate

docs.title: Install Dependencies
docs.text:
# Install production + development dependencies
pip install --upgrade pip
pip install -r requirements.txt -r requirements-dev.txt

# Install GAIA in editable mode
pip install -e .

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text:
# Check imports work
python -c "import core; import overlay; import bridge; print('✅ GAIA dependencies OK')"

# Check tools installed
ruff --version
black --version
mypy --version
pytest --version
mkdocs --version

Expected output: 

✅ GAIA dependencies OK
ruff 0.1.15
black, 23.12.1
mypy 1.8.0
pytest 7.4.3
mkdocs, version 1.5.3

docs.title: 2. Install Pre-commit Hooks
docs.text:
Pre-commit hooks automatically run code quality checks before each commit.

# Install hooks (one-time setup)
pre-commit install

# Test hooks manually
pre-commit run --all-files

What gets checked: 1. Ruff - Linting (errors, style, imports) 2. Black - Code formatting (auto-fix) 3. Mypy - Type checking (core modules) 4. Pytest - Fast unit tests 5. Standard checks - Trailing whitespace, YAML syntax, etc.

docs.title: Create Feature Branch
docs.text: git checkout -b feature/your-feature-name

docs.title: Make Changes
docs.text: Edit code, add tests, update docs.

docs.title: Run Tests
docs.text:
# Run all tests
pytest

# Run specific test file
pytest tests/test_zscore.py

# Run with coverage
pytest --cov=core --cov=overlay --cov-report=html

# Skip slow tests (integration)
pytest -m "not slow"

docs.title: Commit Changes
docs.text:
git add .
git commit -m "feat: add your feature"

# Pre-commit hooks run automatically!
# If checks fail, fix issues and commit again

docs.title: Push and Create PR
docs.text:
git push origin feature/your-feature-name

# Create Pull Request on GitHub
# CI/CD will run automatically

docs.title: Test Structure
docs.text:
tests/
├── core/
│   ├── test_zscore.py
│   └── test_crisis_detector.py
├── overlay/
│   ├── test_avatar_personality.py
│   └── test_avatar_memory.py
└── integration/
    └── test_websocket_server.py

docs.title: Run Tests
docs.text:
# All tests
pytest

# Specific module
pytest tests/core/

# Specific test
pytest tests/core/test_zscore.py::TestZScoreCalculator::test_calculate

# With markers
pytest -m unit         # Fast unit tests only
pytest -m integration  # Integration tests only
pytest -m "not slow"   # Skip slow tests

# Verbose output
pytest -v

# Stop on first failure
pytest -x

# Show print statements
pytest -s

docs.title: Coverage Reports
docs.text:
# Generate HTML coverage report
pytest --cov=core --cov=overlay --cov-report=html

# Open in browser
open htmlcov/index.html  # Mac
xdg-open htmlcov/index.html  # Linux
start htmlcov/index.html  # Windows

docs.title: Linting (Ruff)
docs.text:
# Check for issues
ruff check core/ overlay/ bridge/

# Auto-fix simple issues
ruff check --fix core/ overlay/ bridge/

# Check specific file
ruff check core/zscore/calculator.py

docs.title: Formatting (Black)
docs.text:
# Format all code
black core/ overlay/ bridge/

# Check formatting (no changes)
black --check core/ overlay/ bridge/

# Format specific file
black core/zscore/calculator.py

docs.title: Type Checking (Mypy)
docs.text:
# Check types
mypy core/ overlay/ bridge/

# Check specific module
mypy core/zscore/

# Strict mode (core only)
mypy --strict core/

docs.title: Run All Quality Checks
docs.text: pre-commit run --all-files

docs.title: Serve Docs Locally
docs.text:
# Start local server (hot reload)
mkdocs serve

# Open browser to: http://127.0.0.1:8000/

docs.title: Build Docs
docs.text:
# Build static site
mkdocs build

# Output: site/ directory

docs.title: Deploy Docs
docs.text:
# Deploy to GitHub Pages (main branch only)
mkdocs gh-deploy

# URL: https://xxkylesteenxx.github.io/GAIA.../

docs.title: Add New Page
docs.text:
1. Create Markdown file in docs/
  2. Add to mkdocs.yml navigation
  3. Commit and push (auto-deploys)

docs.title: Add New Dependency
docs.text:
# Production dependency
echo "new-package>=1.0.0" >> requirements.txt

# Development dependency
echo "new-dev-tool>=1.0.0" >> requirements-dev.txt

# Install
pip install -r requirements.txt -r requirements-dev.txt

# Document in docs/dependencies.md

docs.title: Add New Test
docs.text:
# tests/core/test_new_feature.py
import pytest
from core import NewFeature

def test_new_feature():
    """Test new feature works correctly."""
    feature = NewFeature()
    result = feature.do_thing()
    assert result == expected_value

@pytest.mark.slow
def test_new_feature_integration():
    """Integration test (marked as slow)."""
    # Slow test code
    pass

docs.title: Update Documentation
docs.text:
# Edit Markdown file
vim docs/architecture/overview.md

# Preview changes
mkdocs serve

# Commit and push (auto-deploys)
git add docs/
git commit -m "docs: update architecture overview"
git push

docs.title: Fix Failing CI
docs.text:
# Check CI logs on GitHub
# Run same checks locally:

# 1. Quality checks
pre-commit run --all-files

# 2. Tests
pytest -v

# 3. Build
python -m build

# 4. Docs
mkdocs build --strict

docs.title: Import Errors
docs.text:
# Install in editable mode
pip install -e .

# Check PYTHONPATH
echo $PYTHONPATH

# Add to PYTHONPATH (temporary)
export PYTHONPATH="$PWD:$PYTHONPATH"

docs.title: Pre-commit Failures
docs.text:
# Run hooks manually to see details
pre-commit run --all-files

# Update hooks
pre-commit autoupdate

# Skip hooks (emergency only!)
git commit --no-verify

docs.title: Test Failures
docs.text:
# Run with verbose output
pytest -vv

# Show print statements
pytest -s

# Drop into debugger on failure
pytest --pdb

# Run specific failing test
pytest tests/core/test_zscore.py::test_failing_test -vv

docs.title: Documentation Build Errors
docs.text:
# Strict mode (shows warnings as errors)
mkdocs build --strict

# Validate YAML
python -c "import yaml; yaml.safe_load(open('mkdocs.yml'))"

# Check broken links
mkdocs build && python -m http.server --directory site

docs.title: Factor 13 (Universal Love)
docs.text:
• NEVER bypass crisis detection
  • ALWAYS test emergency override
  • NEVER create duplicate Z-score calculations
  • ALWAYS use canonical imports from core

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text:
• Type hints: Use for all function signatures in core/
  • Docstrings: Google style for all public functions
  • Line length: 100 characters (enforced by Black)
  • Imports: Sorted automatically by Ruff

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
• Coverage: Aim for >80% in core/, >60% overall
  • Markers: Use @pytest.mark.slow for integration tests
  • Fixtures: Share test data via fixtures in conftest.py
  • Mocking: Use pytest-mock for external dependencies

docs.title: Commits
docs.text:
• Format: type: description (e.g., feat: add Z-score cache)
  • Types: feat, fix, docs, test, refactor, chore
  • Size: Small, focused commits (easier to review)
  • Pre-commit: Let it run! Catches issues early
